result.execSummary:
Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Paula M. Smekofske

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt:
ADDRESS INFO for Paula M. Smekofske
Current: 521 Naragansette Ave, Baraboo, WI 53913 United States  (Effective: 08-31-2017)
Prior: 109 Maplewood Court #38, Black River Falls, WI 54615

Defendant appears in person in custody without counsel present.  Rebecca Maki-Wallander appears as Special Prosecutor for the State.  Defendant wishes to proceed today without an attorney.  16CF75 - Defendant has completed the waiver of preliminary hearing form.  Judge questions her regarding her respones on waiver form.  She meant to mark "no" that there hasn't been any threats or promises to waive.  That was an error on defendant's part.  Court finds the defendant knowingly and intelligently waives her right to a preliminary hearing and acccepts her waiver of the preliminary hearing.  She is bound over for trial.  State files the Information.  Court reviews that the charges/potential penalties which are the same as the original complaint.  Waives the reading of the Information.  Defendant wishes to plead guilty.  Court has concerns as she hasn't spoken to an attorney and hasn't had a pre-trial.  She did receive a recommendation from the State that is for both cases.  16CM75 - Court reviews the charge and potential penalties.  Defendant understands the charge and penalties.  She will enter a no contest plea on this case.  Court reviews the plea questionnaire as it is not filled out correctly.  Judge performs colloquy of the plea questionnaire/elements/waiver of rights with defendant on 16CF75.  Felony warning given.  Court accepts her waivers and understands the proceedings.  Court makes a finding of guilty.  16CM75 - case is dismissed and read-in.  State gives their recommendation of probation on 16CF75 for 27 months with conditions:  The defendant shall undergo a risk and needs assessment and comply with all recommendations.  Defendant excercises her right to allocution and also states her position on the State's recommendation for probation and gives her own recommendation for sentencing of jail term on each case.  Defendant is not eligible for Healing to Wellness Court with HCN.  She was previously in the JC Treatment Court until it was ended due to lack of a provider for the participants.  Court explains to defendant that the County will be starting another Treatment Court soon if she would consider participating again.  She is set to release sometime in September from sentence now serving.  State gives alternative recommendation of 6-7 months concurrent to term now serving.  16CF75 - Court orders 6 months jail concurrent with sentence now serving; costs, must submit DNA sample and pay the surcharge.
Plea/sentencing hearing on June 6, 2016 at 10:00 am.

State appeared by Special Prosecutor Rebecca Maki Wallender.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody and without counsel.   Right to attorney and waiver form filed with the court.  Court recited the charge and possible penalties contained in the complaint.  She understood.  Reading of the complaint waived.  Defendant plead no contest to the charge. Plea/sentencing set for 6/6/16 at 10 am.  Plea questionnaire and appeal rights forms given to the defendant.

Court questioned defendant on her understanding of the waiver.  Defendant stated she understood.  Court found that defendant freely, voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently waived her right to attorney.
Court questioned defendant on her understanding of the waiver.  Defendant stated she understood.  Court found that defendant knowingly and intelligently waived her right to attorney.

State appeared by special pros. Rebecca Maki Wallender.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody and without counsel.  Defendant has not contacted SPD yet.  Court explained her attorney options.  She wishes to represent herself.  Reset to 1:00 today.
